chapter.title: Intrusion Prevention
chapter.para:
The Intrusion Prevention Appliance is identified by the
symbol. If the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is not installed, please refer to for installation instructions.

As its name implies, the Intrusion Prevention Appliance serves to prevent known malicious exploits from entering your protected network. It is based on technology from Snort.org. The Snort community maintains data on known exploits, and produces lists of signatures for these exploits. The Intrusion Prevention Appliance then interprets these lists to protect your network. Note that with the exception of the , configuration of the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is an advanced topic.

sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The interface for the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is presented as three tabs. The first two tabs, discussed in and , allow the administrator to configure advanced settings. The last tab, , allows administrators to view intrusion scanning events (see ).

sect2.title: Rule List
sect2.para: The interface for the Rule List tab of the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is seen in .

As stated previously, the Intrusion Prevention Appliance is based on technology from Snort.org. Adding or modifying rules in the syntax defined by Snort.org is a advanced topic, and will not be covered in this manual.

All that the average Administrator may want to do is to alter the block or log values for a given rule. The block field causes the Intrusion Prevention Appliance to block traffic matching the given pattern. The log field causes the Intrusion Prevention Appliance to log traffic which matches the rule's pattern.
The Intrusion Prevention Appliance ships with a default set of rules set to block harmful traffic. You should only disable such a rule if a unique software you use happens to collide with a rule.

sect2.title: Rule List
sect2.para: The Events tab contents is shown in .

The Events Tab is another implementation of an Event Log, as described in . The complete list of columns and their meaning is as follows.
Events Tab
timestamp
The time the event took place
action
The action which took place (e.g. block).
client
The client IP address of the traffic.
reason for action
The rule number which cause the event to take place. All Intrusion Prevention Appliance rules are numbered, as shown in .
direction
The direction (inbound or outbound) of the traffic. Most Intrusion Prevention Appliance rules only apply to the inbound (into the protected network) direction.
server
The intended server IP address of the traffic.
